key_points: California has started sending $600 Golden State Stimulus payments to millions of low-income households.
Gov. Gavin Newsom proposes expanding the program to include California’s middle class, tripling the investment to $11.9 billion.
The expansion would allow taxpayers earning up to $75,000 in adjusted gross income to qualify for the stimulus check.
Families with dependents, and those with undocumented workers filing taxes, could receive additional funds.
The initiative aims to benefit 78% of California taxpayers, covering two in three Californians.
People who received the first round of payments are generally not eligible for the second, with certain exceptions for taxpayers with dependents.
The plan requires legislative approval by June 15, with hopes to distribute payments quickly thereafter.
The first round targeted low-income taxpayers, families with children in CalWORKS, and recipients of certain state benefits.
Undocumented tax filers were eligible for the first round if they met income criteria, with certain adjustments for those making less than $30,000.
As of early May, the state's tax agency distributed 2.5 million payments worth $1.6 billion from the first round, with more payments pending.
